lesson.name: Lesson 4.17: The nth Term of an Arithmetic Sequence

page.title: 4.17.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn how a function can be represented by two different equations. You will find any term of an arithmetic sequence directly, by using the nth term formula to find any term number \(n\).

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe the nth term.
  • Find terms of sequences directly.
  • Explain why different equations can represent the same sequence.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.17.1: Repeated Addition Is Multiplication
  • 4.17.2: Define a Sequence by the nth Term
  • 4.17.2: Self Check
  • 4.17.3: Identify a Domain for a Function
  • 4.17.3: Self Check
  • 4.17.4: Interchanging Between Formulas
  • 4.17.4: Self Check
  • 4.17.5: Different Types of Equations

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.17.6: Practice

page.title: 4.17.1: Repeated Addition Is Multiplication
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Which one doesn’t belong?

A. \(5+2+2+2+2+2+2\)

B. \(5+6 \cdot 2\)

C. \(5 \cdot 2^6\)

D. \(5 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\)


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

A doesn’t belong because:

  • It is the only expression with repeated addition.
  • It is the only expression that only has addition.

B doesn’t belong because:

  • It is the only expression with both addition and multiplication.

C doesn’t belong because:

  • It is the only expression with an exponent.

D doesn’t belong because:

  • It is the only expression with repeated multiplication.
  • It is the only expression that only has multiplication.

page.title: 4.17.2: Define a Sequence by the nth Term
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Clare takes a piece of paper with length 8 inches and width 10 inches and cuts it in half. Then she cuts it in half again, and again . . .

  1. Instead of writing a recursive definition, Clare writes \(C(n)=80 \cdot(\frac12)^n\), where \(C\) is the area, in square inches, of the paper after \(n\) cuts. Explain where the different terms in her expression came from.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Each cut halves the area, and there are \(n\) cuts. The original area is 80, so \(80 \cdot \frac12 \cdot \frac12 \cdot \cdot \cdot \cdot \cdot \frac12\) with \(n\) multiplications of \(\frac12\) is the same as saying \(80 \cdot (\frac{1}{2})^n\).



  1. Approximately what is the area of the paper after 10 cuts?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Approximately 0.078 square inches (exactly \(\frac{80}{1024}\) inches)


  1. Kiran takes a piece of paper with length 8 inches and width 10 inches and cuts away 1 inch of the width. Then he does it again, and again . . .
    1. Complete the table for the area of Kiran’s paper \(K(n)\), in square inches, after \(n\) cuts.

\(n\)

\(K(n)\)

0

80

1

2

\(80−8−8=80−8(2)=64\)

3

4

5

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

When \(n\) is 1, \(K(n)\) is 72.
When \(n\) is 3, \(K(n)\) is 56.
When \(n\) is 4, \(K(n)\) is 48.
When \(n\) is 5, \(K(n)\) is 40.



  1. Kiran says the area after 6 cuts, in square inches, is \(80−8 \cdot6\). Explain where the different terms in his expression came from.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Each cut removes 8 square inches, so 6 cuts removes 48 square inches. The original area was 80 square inches, so the remaining area, in square inches, is \(80−8 \cdot 6\).



  1. Write a definition for \(K(n)\) that is not recursive.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\( K(n)=80−8n\) for integers \(0\leq n\leq9\) or equivalent.


  1. Which is larger, \(K(6)\) or \(C(6)\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(K(6)\) is larger.


  1. Is \(K(n)\) arithmetic or geometric?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(K(n)\) is arithmetic.


  1. Is \(C(n)\) arithmetic or geometric?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(C(n)\) is geometric.


A recursive sequence is a sequence in which terms are defined using one or more of the previous terms. If you know the nth term of an arithmetic or geometric sequence and the common difference or factor, you can find the (n+1)th term by using the recursive formula.  

Different definitions can often create the same sequence. For arithmetic and geometric sequences, there are general rules, called explicit rules, that can be followed to help find any term in the sequences. 

These are called the nth term or the general term of the sequence.

Write these definitions down in your math notebook:

Arithmetic Sequence:

\(a_n=a_1+(n-1)d\)

Where \(a_1\) is the first term, \(n\) is the term you want, and \(d\) is the common difference.

Geometric Sequence:

\(a_n=a_1r^{n-1}\)

Where \(a_1\) is the first term, \(n\) is the term you want, and \(r\) is the common ratio.

In the next activity, you will explore how different definitions can represent the same sequence.

page.title: 4.17.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
The nth Term of Arithmetic Sequences

GENERAL TERM (NTH TERM) OF AN ARITHMETIC SEQUENCE

The general term of an arithmetic sequence with first term \(a_1\) and common difference \(d\) is: \(a_n=a_1+(n-1)d\).

We will use this formula in the next example to find the 15th term of a sequence.

Find the 15th term of a sequence where the first term is 3 and the common difference is 6.

To find the fifteenth term, \(a_{15}\), use the
formula with \(a_1=3\) and \(d=6\).

\(a_n=a_1+(n−1)d\)

Substitute in the values.

\(a_{15}=3+(15−1)6\)

Simplify.

\(a_{15}=3+(14)6\)

\(a_{15}=87\)



Try It: The nth Term of Arithmetic Sequences


Find the 27th term of a sequence where the first term is 7 and the common difference is 9.

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find the 27th term of the sequence:

Write the formula.

\(a_n=a_1+(n−1)d\)

Substitute \(a_1=7\), \(d=9\), \(n=27\).

\(a_{27}=7+(27-1)9\)

Simplify inside the parentheses.

\(a_{27}=7+(26)9\)

Simplify to find \(a_{27}\).

\(a_{27}=241\)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 4.17.3: Identify a Domain for a Function
page.contents:
Activity

A Sierpinski triangle can be created by starting with an equilateral triangle, breaking the triangle into 4 congruent equilateral triangles, and then removing the middle triangle. Starting from a single black equilateral triangle:



  1. Let \(S\) be the number of black triangles in Step \(n\). Define \(S(n)\) recursively.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(S(1)=3\), \(S(n)=3 \cdot S(n−1)\) for \(n\geq2\).



  1. Andre and Lin are asked to write an equation for \(S\) that isn’t recursive. Andre writes \(S(n)=3^n\) for \(n\geq0\), while Lin writes \(S(n)=3^n−1\) for \(n\geq1\). Whose equation do you think is correct? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

They are both correct. Sample response: Lin is correct because if the image shows Steps 1 to 4, her equation gives the correct number of triangles for each step. Andre is correct since if we start with the black triangle, which is like Step 0, then Step 1 is the one with 3 triangles and Step 2 has 9 triangles, and those numbers match his equation.

page.title: 4.17.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
The nth Term of a Geometric Sequence

General Term (nth Term) of a Geometric Sequence

The general term of a geometric sequence with first term \(a_1\) and the common ratio \(r\) is: \(a_n=a_1r^{n-1}\).


We will use this formula in the next example to find the 14th term of a sequence.


Find the 14th term of a sequence where the first term is 64 and the common ratio is \(r=\frac12\).

Solution

To find the 14th term, \(a_{14}\), use the formula with \(a_1=64\) and \(r=\frac12\).

\(a_n=a_1r^{n−1}\)

Substitute in the values.

\(a_{14}=64(\frac12)^{14−1}\)

Simplify.

\(a_{14}=64(\frac12)^{13}\)

\(a_{14}=\frac{1}{128}\)


Try It: The nth Term of a Geometric Sequence


Find the 11th term of a sequence where the first term is 81 and the common ratio is \(r=\frac13\).


In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find the 11th term of the sequence:

Write the formula.

\(a_n=a_1r^{n-1}\)

Substitute \(n=11\), \(r=\frac13\), and \(a_1=81\).

\(a_{11}=81(\frac13)^{11-1}\)

Simplify to find \(a_{11}\).

\(a_{11}=81(\frac13)^{10}\)

\(a_{11}=\frac{81}{59049}=\frac1{729}\)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 4.17.4: Interchanging Between Formulas
page.contents:
Activity

Converting from a Recursive Formula to an Explicit Formula

An arithmetic sequence has the following recursive formula:

\(a_1=3\)

\(a_n=a_{n-1}+3\), \(n\geq2\)

Recall that this formula gives us the following two pieces of information:

  • The first term is 3.
  • To get any term from its previous term, add 2. In other words, the common difference is 2.

Let’s find an explicit formula for the sequence.

We can represent a sequence whose first term is \(A\) and common difference is \(B\) with the standard explicit form \(A+B(n−1)\).

Therefore, an explicit formula of the sequence is \(a_n=3+2(n−1)\).


  1. Write an explicit (nth term) formula for an arithmetic sequence where \(b_1=2\) and \(b_n=b_{n-1}+7\), \(n\geq2\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(b_n=2+(n-1)7\)


Now try to take the nth term formula and use it to write the recursive formula of an arithmetic sequence.

We are given the following nth term of an arithmetic sequence:

\(d_n=5+(n-1)16\)

This formula is given in the standard explicit form \(A+B(n−1)\), where \(A\) is the first term and \(B\) is the common difference. Therefore, the first term of the sequence is 5, and the common difference is 16.

Let’s find a recursive formula for the sequence. Recall that the recursive formula gives us two pieces of information:

  • The first term, which we know is 5.
  • The pattern rule to get any term from the term that comes before it, which we know is “add 16.”

Therefore, this is a recursive formula for the sequence: \(d_1=5\), \(d_n=5+(n-1)16\), \(n\geq2\).


  1. Write the recursive formula of \(e_n=12+(n-1)2\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(e_1=12\), \(e_n=e_{n-1}+2\), \(n\geq2\)


Now change the recursive formula of a geometric sequence into the nth term.

Here is the recursive formula of a geometric sequence, \(g(n)\):

\(g_1=9\), \(g_n=g_{n-1} \cdot (8)\), \(n\geq2\)

9 is the first term of the sequence, and 8 is the common ratio.

An explicit formula is structured as: \(g(x)=\) (1st term of sequence) \(\cdot\) (common ratio)\(^{(x-1)}\).

Substitute the values, and you get the explicit formula: \(g_n= 9 \cdot 8^{(n-1)}\).


  1. Write the nth term of the geometric sequence where \(g_1=5\) and \(g_n=g_{n-1} \cdot 4\), \(n\geq2\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(g_n=-5 \cdot 4^{(n-1)}\)


Finally, geometric sequences represented by the nth term can be represented with the recursive definition.

Start with the nth term formula for \(g_n\) where \(g_n=6 \cdot 3^{n-1}\).

Working backward, when \(n=1\), \(g_1=6\). This is the initial term.

The formula for geometric sequences recursively is \(g_n=g_{n-1} \cdot r\), where \(r\) is the common ratio.

The common ratio of the given sequence is 3.

So, \(g_1=6\) and \(g_n=g_{n-1} \cdot 3\), \(n\geq2\).

  1. Write the geometric sequence represented by \(g_n=14 \cdot 2^{n-1}\) using the recursive definition.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(g_1=14\), \(g_n=g_{n-1} \cdot2\), \(n\geq2\)

page.title: 4.17.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Switching Between Definitions of Sequences

A recursive formula defines each term of a sequence using the previous terms.

An explicit or nth term formula defines the terms of the sequence using their position in the sequence, without knowing any other terms in the sequence.

Sequence

Recursive Formula

Explicit or nth Term Formula

Arithmetic

\(F_1=a_1\), \(F_n=F_{n-1}+d\), where \(a_1\) is the first term and \(d\) is the common difference.

\(a_n=a_1+(n-1)d\), where \(a_1\) is the first term, \(n\) is the term you want, and \(d\) is the common difference.

Geometric

\(H_1=a_1\), \(H_n=H_{n-1} \cdot r\), where \(a_1\) is the first term and \(r\) is the common ratio.

\(a_n=a_1r^{n-1}\), where \(a_1\) is the first term, \(n\) is the term you want, and \(r\) is the common ratio.

Find the explicit formula for each sequence given in recursive form:

  1. \(a_1=5\), \(a_n=a_{n-1}+6\), \(n\geq2\)

Write the recursive formula.

\(a_1=5\), \(a_n=a_{n-1}+6\), \(n\geq2\)

Identify the first term.

\(a_1=5\)

Identify the common difference.

\(d=6\)

Write the explicit formula.

\(a_n=a_1+(n-1)d\)

Substitute \(a_1\) and \(d\) into the formula.

\(a_n=5+(n-1)6\)

Check by finding the first 3 terms using each formula:

\(a_1=5\), \(a(n)=a_n=a_{n-1}+6\), \(n\geq2\)

\(a_1=5\)

\(a_2=5+6=11\)

\(a_3=11+6=17\)

\(a_n=5+(n-1)6\)

\(a_1=5\)

\(a_2=5+(2-1)6=11\)

\(a_3=5+(3-1)6=17\)

Both formulas produce the same first 3 terms: 5, 11, 17.

  1. \(b_1=4\), \(b_n=b_{n-1} \cdot 5\), \(n\geq2\)

Write the recursive formula.

\(b_1=4\), \(b_n=b_{n-1} \cdot 5\), \(n\geq2\)

Identify the first term.

\(a_1=4\)

Identify the common ratio.

\(r=5\)

Write the explicit formula.

\(a_n=a_1r^{n-1}\)

Substitute \(a_1\) and \(r\) into the formula.

\(a_n=4(5)^{n-1}\)

Check by finding the first 3 terms using each formula:

\(b_1=4\), \(b_n=b_{n-1} \cdot 5\), \(n\geq2\)

\(a_1=4\)

\(b_2=b_{2-1} \cdot 5=4 \cdot 5=20\)

\(b_3=b_{3-1} \cdot 5=20 \cdot 5=100\)

\(a_n=4(5)^{n-1}\)

\(a_1=4(5)^{1-1}=4\)

\(a_2=4(5)^{2-1}=20\)

\(a_3=4(5)^{3-1}=100\)

Both formulas produce the same first 3 terms: 4, 20, 100.

Find the recursive formula for each sequence given in explicit form:

  1. \(a_n=21+(n-1)(-2)\)

Write the explicit formula.

\(a_n=21+(n-1)(-2)\)

Identify the first term.

\(a_1=21\)

Identify the common difference.

\(d=-2\)

Write the recursive formula.

\(F_1=a_1\), \(F_n=F_{n-1}+d\), \(n\geq2\)

Substitute \(a_1\) and \(d\) into the formula.

\(F_1=21\), \(F_n=F_{n-1}-2\), \(n\geq2\)

Both formulas produce the same first 3 terms: 21, 19, 17.

  1. \(a_n=3 \cdot (\frac14)^{n-1}\)

Write the explicit formula.

\(a_n=3 \cdot (\frac14)^{n-1}\)

Identify the first term.

\(a_1=3\)

Identify the common ratio.

\(r= \frac14\)

Write the recursive formula.

\(H_1=a_1\), \(H_n=H_{n-1} \cdot R\), \(n\geq2\)

Substitute \(a_1\) and \(r\) into the formula.

\(H_1=3\), \(H_n=H_{n-1} \cdot \frac14\), \(n\geq2\)

Both formulas produce the same first three terms: 3, \(\frac34\), \(\frac{3}{16}\).

Try It: Switching Between Definitions of Sequences

Write the recursive formula for the sequence below that is given in explicit form:

\(a_n=14+(n-1)(3)\)


In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to write the sequence using the recursive definition:

Write the explicit formula.

\(a_n=14+(n-1)(3)\)

Identify the first term.

\(a_1=14\)

Identify the common difference.

\(d=3\)

Write the recursive formula.

\(F1=a_1\), \(F_n=F_{n-1}+d\), \(n\geq2\)

Substitute \(a_1\) and \(d\) into the formula.

\(F_1=14\), \(F_n=F_{n-1}+3\), \(n\geq2\)

Both formulas give the same first 3 terms: 14, 17, 20.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 4.17.5: Different Types of Equations
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity


  1. A sequence is defined by \(f_1=-3\), \(f_n=f_{n-1}+0.5\) for \(n\geq2\). Diego writes an equation for the nth term of the sequence as \(a_n=-3+(n-1)(0.5)\). Is he correct? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes. Sample response: Both definitions create a sequence that starts at –3 and increases by 0.5 each term.


  1. How would you describe the representation \(f_1=-3\), \(f_n=f_{n-1}+0.5\) for \(n\geq2\) for Diego’s sequence?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It is the recursive definition of the sequence.


  1. How would you describe the representation of Diego’s sequence, \(a_n=-3+(n-1)(0.5)\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

This is the nth term of the sequence.
